}}

'''David Hamilton''' is a doctor who courted Meredith to work on a special project to treat his Parkinson's.



In , he worked with Ellis for a few months just as she was starting to show signs of Alzheimer's. He noticed the signs, but didn't know what they meant. When he asked her about them, she bit his head off. ''("[[Bottle Up and Explode!]]")''


David invited Meredith to come to Minnesota as they were dedicating a research library to her mother. When she arrived, he gave her a tour of the facility and told her he was doing additional research into mRNA technology as part of vaccine development and cancer treatment. He then showed her a research lab that he'd had set up and asked her to work there, developing a cure for Parkinson's, a condition which he had.

He then took her out to dinner, where he elaborated on the proposed treatment and talked to Meredith about his own treatment, which he said usually worked well enough to get him through consults with patients before wearing off. ''("[[Here Comes the Sun]]")''

As Meredith considered his offer, she brought Amelia to Minnesota to tour the facility and examine David. She asked if he'd considered options like deep-brain stimulation, but he said he wanted a cure, which is why she was there. They just needed Meredith to say yes. At the end of the day, Meredith said she needed full autonomy to pick the team, wanted everything they learned to be accessible to anyone with Parkinson's, and asked to have the project moved to Grey Sloan. David said he couldn't do that, but did agree to let Meredith set up a satellite lab there so she could do most of her work there and travel to Minnesota once a week. ''("[[Some Kind of Tomorrow]]")''


David observed as research began. The first step was proving that the cells could stay alive after being injected. David became irritated when he learned that Meredith had brought Tom Koracick onto the project as Koracick had slept with his daughter, which David didn't like. Meredith reminded him that he had given her full autonomy over the staff for the project and Amelia needed a second neurosurgeon. ''("[[Bottle Up and Explode!]]")''


One morning, shortly after Thanksgiving, David called an emergency team meeting. When he arrived, he told them that he had sprained his wrist falling in his bedroom becuase his foot froze up. He was angry because his disease was progressing faster than the research. He demanded they work quicker to meet the FDA's criteria for a one-time compassionate use for him. After a long day of trials, David visited the lab and drew their attention to a sample which had % viability, enough to satisfy the FDA's requirement. ''("[[Today Was a Fairytale]]")''


Knowing doing the surgery in Minnesota would draw too much unwanted attention, David and Kai traveled to Seattle so he could have his surgery there instead once hte FDA approved them to do the surgery within in a limited window. Because of this time limit, David lied and told Meredith he was fine even when he started feeling pain in his abdomen. He then developed a low-grade fever, which he also tried to brush off. Meredith examined him and then ordered a CT, which showed a perforated bowel. Meredith took him into surgery, but he became hypotensive while she scrubbed in, forcing her to rush in soon after and start his surgery. ''("[[It Came Upon a Midnight Clear]]")''

After his surgery, Meredith and Kai both chastised him for not telling them about his pain. Meredith said if he did it again, she would leave the program, which would cause the FDA to pull their approval. ''("[[No Time to Die]]")''


Once he'd sufficiently healed from that surgery, they prepared for his experimental treatment. On the day of surgery, as he got last-minute tests and they prepared the cells, Hamilton documented the process, saying it was for the book he was planing to write. Hamilton wanted the surgery to be private, but Meredith told him it was teaching hospital and she wanted to open the surgery up for all hospital staff to observe. Hamilton reluctantly agreed. Once everything was ready, Hamilton was taken to the OR, where he was secured into a halo and the cells were injected. ''("[[Legacy]]")''


Back in Minnesota, Meredith presented Hamilton's case to the staff of the Mayo Clinic. While she reported more scientifically on his progress, he was more grandiose, stating that he and his wife had played chess and his hand hadn't shaken at all. Then he surprised Meredith by offering her a permanent position in front of everyone as director of The Grey Center and Head of General Surgery. Later, away from the crowd, he showed her the new budget that had been approved for the Grey Center, which included her salary. ''("[[Put the Squeeze On Me]]")''


David and Kai came to Seattle on Richard's request to test his skills to see if he needed to retire. The testing was interrupted when Richard got a call from Levi Schmitt and left to help him treat his mother, causing Kai to question his judgment, as he hadn't said a word to them before leaving. While Richard spoke to [[Jamarah Blake]] and [[MaryAnn Suchan]] about the residency program, they taped Levi Schmitt speaking about his own experience with the team. Richard then returned to the testing room and completed his tests. Kai told him he'd passed. ''("[[Put It to the Test]]")''



He is married. Prior to his sugery, he left a note for his wife on his computer in case he didn't make it. ''("[[It Came Upon a Midnight Clear]]")''


He has a daughter and a granddaughter, who is twelve. ''("[[Today Was a Fairytale]]")'' Before his surgery, he wrote notes to his children and grandchildren for Meredith to send to them if he didn't make it. ''("[[It Came Upon a Midnight Clear]]")''


He knew [[Ellis Grey]] when she was alive. He also did the conference circuit with Richard, who said David would make a terrible boss.


He is an [[Attending|attending]] [[General Surgery|general surgeon]] at [[Mayo Clinic|The Mayo Clinic]] in Rochester, MN. [[Richard Webber|Dr. Webber]] described him as Minnesota's prized tumor guy. Because of his Parkinson's diagnosis, he is retired from surgery but still consults on general surgery patients. Additionally, because of his diagnosis, he founded [[The Grey Center]] with the hopes of curing his disease. ''("[[Here Comes the Sun]]")''


*He is self-proclaimed as "Minnesota's [retired] Thoroughbred" but still "pretty good".<ref>[[Here Comes the Sun]], x</ref>
*He says he never really worked out what he believed in religiously.<ref>[[It Came Upon a Midnight Clear]], x</ref>

'''David Roman''' is a young man who tried to cut off his own hand because be believed it was causing him to sin.


David believed he was sinning by masturbating, so he followed a passage in the Bible that says you should cut off your hand if it's causing you to sin. However, after he cut into his wrist, he called  and was taken to the hospital. They had to reattach his tendons and stitch up his wrist, but he was told he'd be okay with some rehabilitation. The psych consult they called was taking time, so they brought in Carina DeLuca to talk to him about the benefits of masturbation. She told him it was normal and admitted that she did it herself, which caused him to get an erection, so he asked her to leave immediately, which she did.


*He was  at the time of his hospitalization.

'''Denise''' is the best friend of [[Roberta Gibbs]].


Denise came to the hospital when her best friend, Roberta, was called there for a liver transplant. Roberta was worried the transplant would fall through again as it had before and shared her funeral plans with Denise, making her promise to let everyone grieve the way they wanted as she hadn't been allowed to do for her father. Denise said she wanted Roberta to live and was upset that Roberta was planning her funeral. When they learned about a liver that had been taken out of a newly dead man and reperfused, Roberta agreed to let them try it on her if they got approval. The transplant went forward and Roberta was expected to make a full recovery.



She and [[Roberta Gibbs]] are best friends. When Roberta was in the hospital awaiting a liver transplant, she talked to Denise about what things she wanted for her funeral.

'''Devon Gomez''' is a patient who was at the hospital to have an ileostomy reversed.


Devon had been diagnosed with ulcerative colitis, which he had an ileostomy to treat. Later, he returned to have the ileostomy reversed. Prior to his surgery, he met his surgeons and one of him recognized him as the voice of a podcast he enjoyed. Devon said he'd had to pause the podcast after he was diagnosed because he didn't have the energy to go for walks, which was the basis of his podcast. He hope after having his ileostomy reversed, he'd be able to start it up again. Schmitt asked his permission to listen to his podcast while he operated, which Devon granted. They took him into his surgery, but he started hemorrhaging partway through and they were unable to save him. ''([[It Came Upon a Midnight Clear]]")''


*He had a podcast called "On Foot with Devon," which he had to stop after his first surgery.
*He was pronounced dead at :.

'''Diane Pierce'''\uawas the mother of [[Maggie Pierce]]. She ultimately died of inflammatory breast cancer.



She was born in a two-room shack with an outhouse. ''("[[Be Still, My Soul]]")''

She and her husband adopted Maggie and raised her. The marriage fell apart while they pretended everything was fine to protect Maggie. Diane started an affair of  years with the man who serviced their car.

Diane was very pleased with how easy Maggie was. She never talked back, she had good grades, and her room was always clean. She was concerned when Maggie left Boston for Seattle and called her a lot, but she was happy Maggie did so after learning about the people she met. About a year after Maggie had left the city, Diane and Bill got a divorce, after which Diane moved to Hawaii to make soaps.


When Diane noticed a rash, she went to a local doctor and started treatment, but it didn't look good. As she had always taught her daughter to find the smartest person in the room or otherwise another room, she found [[Jackson Avery]] was the best and also a friend of Maggie's. She scheduled an appointment with him. However, realizing that there was a real chance of her dying soon, she started skydiving and traveling the world. ''("[[What's Inside]]")''


When the time for the appointment came, Diane went to Seattle, a surprise to her daughter. She quickly bonded with all Maggie's colleagues, who all liked her. Jackson examined her rash and took a biopsy, which showed inflammatory breast cancer. She asked him to help her tell Maggie and he said he would and also offered to refer her to local specialists and fly to Hawaii to operate on her.

Diane then went to Meredith's house where she folded laundry, made lasagna, and put the kids to bed. When Maggie came home and confronted her mom about her behavior, Diane decided not to tell her and instead just said she'd leave and when Maggie was ready to have her in her life, she could let Diane know. ''("[[None of Your Business]]")''


Diane came back to Seattle to have her mastectomy. She'd been going to chemotherapy and was getting a good response, but shocked Jackson by telling him she still hadn't told Maggie about the cancer. She wanted to have the surgery and then tell Maggie, but Jackson said he wouldn't go forward with the surgery until she'd told Maggie. After Maggie came in and tried to be supportive, Diane told Maggie about the breast cancer. The next day, she went in for her surgery, but during surgery, the doctors found something unexpected. ''("[[Till I Hear It From You]]")''


After her mastectomy, Diane got the news that her cancer had spread. She had surgery to remove more cancer from her body and continued to have radiation and chemotherapy. When she complained of stomach pain, Meredith ordered a new CT, which showed a met near her liver, which was causing the pain. When Meredith advised against removing it, Maggie pressured Diane to fire her. Maggie then found a clinical trial with promising early results that she could get into if they could lower her LFTs. Bailey figured out a way to place a stent to lower Diane's LFTs and get her into the trial. The procedure worked, but Bailey, Richard, and Jackson didn't think the trial was a good idea. Despite this and Richard advising Diane that it wasn't a good idea, Maggie pushed forward and Diane supported her, believing Maggie wouldn't do anything to hurt her.

Once on the treatment, Diane had multiple side effects. She got an infection in her arm and blood built up. She had to have fluid aspirated from her back, but she eventually started to feel a little better. She taught Maggie to make her lasagna and told Maggie to invite all her friends over to have dinner together. At the dinner, Diane started coughing heavily. She soon coughed up some blood and they rushed her to the hospital. She had a tear in her esophagus, which Richard repaired with difficulty. Maggie wanted to get her up and moving again after the surgery as soon as possible, because she'd lose her spot in the trial if she missed a treatment. Richard went and talked to Diane privately, to tell her she didn't have to keep going with the treatment if she didn't want to. She told him Maggie was a gift to her and if she died, it would give Maggie darkness not to know she did everything she could and she didn't want to do that. Richard told her Maggie was strong and she could handle it. Maggie tried to call around to find newer treatment possibilities for her mother, but Diane told her it was time to stop fighting.

Later, while Diane tried to give Maggie life advice, Maggie painted her nails. When the smell overwhelmed her, Maggie went to open a window and saw that it had stopped raining. When she went back to the bed, her mother was dead. She continued to paint her mom's nails as she cried. ''("[[Be Still, My Soul]]")''

After her death, Jackson saw her loaded file that showed her medical history before she came to see him. He discovered she had already found out she was sick before she came to see him, and he guessed that she came to Seattle because he would do everything possible to cure her because of how close he was to Maggie, as well as take care of Maggie if she really were to die. ''("[[What's Inside]]")''


Diane appeared in Maggie's fever dream as a beacon of warmth and comfort after Maggie had read Ellis's letter. ''("[[The Makings of You]]")''



She was married to Maggie's father. However, she had a long-term affair with the man who fixed their car. They ultimately split up over it. She said leaving Maggie's father was the moment she finally felt like she could breathe again. ''("[[None of Your Business]]")''


When she surprised Maggie with a visit, Maggie was upset that she didn't give her advance warning that she was coming. Maggie also disliked how she quickly bonded with the other doctors at the hospital. ''("[[None of Your Business]]")'' She told Meredith she always wanted to have more kids, so Maggie could have a brother or sister. She was glad when Maggie found Meredith. ''("[[Be Still, My Soul]]")''


Diane quickly bonded with all Maggie's colleagues. She made plans to have dinner with Richard, but cancelled those plans when she was diagnosed with breast cancer. ''("[[None of Your Business]]")''

While she was in chemo, she also formed a relationship with her nurse, Aurora, to the point where she knew Aurora's son, Lee, was re-taking his driver's test, which he'd failed twice before. ''("[[Be Still, My Soul]]")''


She made soap in Hawaii.


*She brought her engagement ring to Seattle with her to give to Maggie.<ref>[[Be Still, My Soul]], x</ref>
*She was afraid of heights.<ref>[[What's Inside]], x</ref>

'''Doug Giles''' is a man who came into the ER after a motorcycle crash.


Doug and his wife, Cheryl, came into the ER after they crashed Doug's new motorcycle. They had just gone for a ride around the block and Doug swerved to avoid hitting a dog. Their daughter, Wynnie, drove them to the hospital in their van with only a learner's permit. In the ER, they learned that while Cheryl had only cuts and bruises on her hand, Doug had a serious head injury because Cheryl had been wearing the only helmet. She said she didn't even like the motorcycle, but she liked seeing Doug in the garage with it and it stirred up feelings. While her hands were bandaged, Doug was taken into surgery to treat a brain bleed. After his surgery, he was expected to recover fully and said he'd be getting rid of the motorcycle.



He is married to [[Cheryl Giles]].


He and Cheryl have two kids: Wynnie and Hank. Wynnie was upset with them after the crash and didn't trust them to make good decisions.


He works in human resources.


*He previously owned a motorcycle in college.

They took him to the OR to repair the artery and wash out the wound. ''("[[It's Raining Men]]")'' On Halloween, Doug treated a child who had put a piece of candy corn up his nose. He pulled the candy out and then was horrified when the child ate it. ''("[[Whistlin' Past the Graveyard]]")'' After transferring to Grey Sloan upon the closing of Pac North, Doug and the other residents practiced procedures in a skills lab. Later, he and the other residents rounded on [[Ava Gutierrez]] with Richard Webber. '''Dr. Safavi''' is [[Frances Pinfield|Frances Pinfield's]] therapist.


When Dr. Safavi learned that his patient, Frances, who had severe agoraphobia, had been asked to come to the United States to donate blood, he was shocked into silence. However, when she said she wanted to do it, he agreed to accompany her. He helped her get through the two flights, but in Seattle, there was a problem with his visa, so he wasn't able to stay with her after arrival.


He is a therapist. He's been working with [[Frances Pinfield]] for two years and initiated exposure therapy for her agoraphobia.

'''Duda Kyat''' is the mother of [[Arthur Kyat]].


Duda's son, Arthur, was in end-stage liver failure due to primary sclerosing cholangitis. He was severely jaundiced and unable to leave his hospital bed. After  days on the transplant list, Nick came to check on him and invited him to a basketball game. His mother was upset, because she said the hope made things harder. Then Nick revealed that a liver had become available and was going to Arthur. Once the liver was retrieved, Nick transplanted it into Arthur. After the surgery was over, Nick told Duda that he would be walking around in a few weeks. She asked Nick how to thank the family that had just lost their loved one.

Near the end of his fellowship, Nico started putting out feelings to find an attending job. He schedule a video interview with E. Hogans at UCSF. Despite having a difficult day including a patient dying due to a mistake he made, Nico took the interview.


He is an orthopedic surgeon at University of California San Francisco.

'''Ed Hamilton''' is the husband of [[Dana Hamilton]] and father of [[Guthrie Hamilton]].


Ed's son, Guthrie, was making croissants in a pastry class when he collapsed. He was diagnosed with a brain tumor which had spread to his spine, causing motor weakness in his limbs and sensory deficits. His mom, desperate to save him, took him to Grey Sloan Memorial to see her ex-husband, Tom, a neurosurgeon. Before they met, she warned Guthrie that since he looked like his deceased brother, it might freak Tom out to meet him. Due to the resemblance and the relationship to Guthrie's mother, Tom said he couldn't do the surgery. However, when Amelia started having contractions during the surgery and believed she was in labor, Tom was forced to step in and take over. Despite a hiccup, he was able to finish the surgery and Dana and Ed were told he'd be okay with some radiation.



He is married to [[Dana Hamilton]].


His son, Guthrie, had a brain tumor that spread to his spine when he was ten years old.

{{DEFAULTSORT:Hamilton, Ed}}

'''Eileen Hillridge''' is the mother of [[Nora Hillridge]].


Eileen's daughter, Nora, had been diagnosed with hereditary pancreatitis at the age of five. They'd spent six years getting her numbers where they needed to be in order to do the pancreatectomy. They also planned islet autotransplantation so she wouldn't develop diabetes. When her numbers were finally all in line, her mother was told she'd be able to have the surgery. However, her blood sugar suddenly spiked with no explanation right before her surgery. They gave her insulin to bring it down and monitored her. While they waited, she did math problems with the doctors, impressing them with her accuracy and speed. While they were doing this, Dahlia discovered an empty juice bottle by her bed and inferred that she drank it in order to raise her blood sugar level. They asked her about it and she said it was because she didn't want to go back to school, because she didn't have any friends. She maintained that she didn't want the surgery. Against Alex's orders, Andrew went to Nora and talked to her about his own experience being bullied and told her she could handle it and convinced her to have the surgery, which went well.



She is very protective of her daughter. When Nora's friend, Lauren, wasn't being kind to her, she called her a bitch in front of Nora.

{{DEFAULTSORT:Hillridge, Eileen}}

Eli was at a convenience store with his Aunt Claire and his brother, [[Gabe]], when his aunt collapsed. They accompanied her to the ER, where she was diagnosed with toxic megacolon and had surgery to remove a portion of her colon. After the surgery, Claire talked to Gabe and Eli about how scary it had been when she collapsed and sent them to the cafeteria to get pizza to eat.



He started living with his aunt and brother after their mother died.

'''Elisa Tang''' is a girl who needed a liver transplant due to alpha--antitrypsin deficiency.


Elisa was born with alpha--antitrypsin deficiency, a liver condition which had killed her older sister without being diagnosed. Her condition rapidly declined, necessitating a liver transplant when she was only six. A liver became available, but was unable to be transported to the hospital due to a blizzard. [[Andrew DeLuca]] then offered to go retrieve the liver on foot, so that Elisa's life might be saved. While he was gone, Elisa's condition continued to decline and she hemorrhaged. They transfused blood and took her into surgery to place a shunt with the hope that it would stop the bleeding. The shunt worked and when the liver arrived, it was successfully transplanted. Her condition started to improve immediately and her parents were told she'd be okay.



Her older sister died of a liver condition that she also inherited.


*She was six at the time of her transplant.

{{DEFAULTSORT:Tang, Elisa}}

'''Ella Nelstadt''' is the daughter of [[Frank Nelstadt]].


Ella went to the ER with one of her dads, Frank, when he had a very severe cough and sore throat. He'd had the cough for a few days and wasn't concerned, but Ella was worried and made him go to the hospital. While he was being examined, he had trouble breathing, which was resolved when he coughed up a blood clot which was shaped like a bronchial tree. When he started to struggle to breathe again, he was taken to have TPA injected to break up the clot. He was then diagnosed with Factor V leiden. As the condition is genetic, Danny, Ella's other dad, immediately said Ella needed to be tested. They never wanted to know which of them was her biological father, but knew they needed to know if she had the same kind of condition, so she could properly maintain her health. The test came back positive, though Ella said it didn't matter because they're both her dads.



She has two fathers. They chose not to know which of them was her biological father, unless she wanted to know. She said she didn't, but when one of her dad was diagnosed with a genetic condition, she was also tested for the condition and it came back positive. She said it didn't change anything for her and they were still both her dads.

{{DEFAULTSORT:Nelstadt, Ella}}

'''Elliott Calhoun''' is a patient who came in for his fourth aortic valve replacement.


Elliott was in the hospital for his fourth aortic valve replacement due to congenital aortic stenosis. While he was fasting in preparation for his surgery, his wife, Finley's, water broke, a month before her due date. Their son, Jasper, was born that day, one month early. He was taken to the NICU, where he was said to be doing well. Elliott was taken into surgery. His valve replacement went well, but his heart didn't restart when they were finished like it should have. Teddy believed it was due to hibernating myocardium and said they just needed to give Elliott more time. They told Finley about this and she was upset that they couldn't tell her definitively that it would work. ''("[[Let's All Go to the Bar]]")''

Not long afterward, Elliott's heart had healed enough that it started beating again. Andrew slowly weaned him off the pacing wires and ECMO and Elliott's condition stabilized. ''("[[Help Me Through the Night]]")''



He is married to [[Finley Calhoun]].


He and his wife have one son, [[Jasper Calhoun]].


*He was  at the time of his fourth valve replacement.

'''Emma Correa''' is a patient who crashed her bike into Teddy and Owen's wedding.


Emma and her wife, Nadia, had just sent their son off to college. Desperate not to become that couple who just grows to hate each other, Emma bought a tandem bike and signed them up for the Undies bike race. They were racing when Emma saw an anti-oil activist with something interesting written on her body, but when she tried to read it, she steered them off the path and into Teddy and Owen's wedding, injuring [[Father Christopher]], the priest marrying them, and both Nadia and Emma. They were taken to the emergency room, where Emma was admitted for observation, while Nadia's more severe injuries were assessed. She had numbness in her feet and an x-ray showed multiple spinal fractures. While they were examining her, she complained that she was overheated, so Link ordered an MRI as he suspected damage to her autonomic nervous system. By the time she got to the MRI, she was freezing. The MRI showed a tethered spinal cord and syrinx. She told the doctors she'd always had trouble with her back, but worked through it and was unaware that her spinal cord was tethered, which was causing the pain. They took her into surgery, where they repaired the first fracture and then flipped her to clip the cord and repair the other fracture. After Amelia clipped the cord, they briefly believed she was paralyzed, but they found that she was just bleeding and they were able to repair the damage. Her wife was told she'd make a full recovery, though the priest they hit died, leaving Emma worried Nadia would continue to hate her, as she believed Nadia already did.



She is married to [[Nadia Correa]].


She and Nadia have a son who just went off to college.

{{DEFAULTSORT:Correa, Emma}}

'''Eric Lincoln''' is the father of [[Atticus Lincoln]].


On the anniversary of the day Link's doctor told him he didn't have cancer anymore, Maureen and Eric came to Seattle to have lunch to celebrate, a tradition. Link said previous meals always devolved into the two them comparing their lives to determine who had a better one since the divorce, but he had high hopes for this one because he and Amelia could tell them they're going to be grandparents. At the lunch, Maureen said she was getting remarried to Eric. He'd moved to Denver for work and joined a dating app to meet people. Maureen was his first match, so he moved to a different app. Two more apps also paired them, so they decided to get coffee and rekindled their relationship. Link was angry because they put him through the wringer getting divorced and always put him between them and now they've worked it out. He told them about the pregnancy and when they were discussing timing of the baby, they noted that they had put a deposit down on a wedding venue, but when that upset Link even more, they said they could change it.


Despite the [[COVID- Pandemic]], Eric and Maureen decided to go forward with their wedding, making their son fearful that they'd get COVID. ''("[[It's All Too Much]]")''

Later, Eric and Maureen bought an RV, packed it with supplies, and drove it from Colorado to Seattle. For two weeks, they had no contact with anyone but each other. When they arrived in Seattle, they were excited to meet Scout and offered to take all four kids to see Mt. Rainier so Amelia and Link could have some time to themselves. ''("[[Sorry Doesn't Always Make It Right]]")''



He is currently engaged to his ex-wife, Maureen. They had a contentious divorce and made their\uason go between them when he was just a child. However, after being apart, they were matched on three different dating websites and decided to get coffee. Things went well between them and they decided to get re-married.


He and Maureen have one son, Link.

'''Erika Swift''' is a patient who was injured while rollerskating with her children.


At the start of the pandemic, Erika decided that if the world was going to end, she might as well be happy, so she quit her job as a tech lawyer and spent some time with her kids and working out. Then she started a business making peanut brittle. She also took up rollerskating with her kids. She wanted to learn the plot stop, but her kids wanted to learn the moonwalk. While attempting this, Erika skated into a railing, causing a serious abdominal injury and breaking her left leg. She was taken to the hospital, where they x-rayed her leg and examined her abdomen. After her tests, she was told they'd cast her leg and observe her abdominal bleeding. When the bleeding worsened, she was taken into surgery.

After her surgery, she asked when she'd be able to work again. She wanted to go back to her job as a lawyer, assuming she could get hired. Bailey talked to her and said that rest wasn't a bad thing and encouraged her to do what she loved instead of returning to the job she hated.



She has at least two children.


She was a tech lawyer, but at the start of the pandemic, she quit that job and opened a business making peanut brittle called Brown Sugar Brittle.


*She lost  pounds after quitting her job.

'''Erin Banks''' ''aka'' '''Cindy Wright''' is a patient who came into the clinic with a woman pretending to be her aunt who was trafficking her.


Erin, known then as Cindy, came into the clinic with Opal, who said she was Cindy's aunt, with abdominal pain, which Andrew diagnosed as a hernia. Andrew was immediately suspicious of the fact that Opal did all the talking while Cindy just stood there. He shared his concerns with [[Nurse Liv]] and asked her to get Bailey for him. Meanwhile, he ran additional tests to keep Opal and Cindy in the clinic. Bailey came down to the clinic, but doubted Andrew's claims. She went to check on Cindy herself and didn't detect anything unusual in their reactions, so she told Andrew to treat Cindy and let it go. Despite this, he persisted. He promised Cindy a spot in Meredith's pro bono surgery day for her hernia and used that as an excuse to get Cindy away. He then questioned her, but she revealed nothing and Opal quickly discovered them. A crowd gathered and they tried to talk Andrew down, even as he continued to call for security to arrest Opal. They eventually got Andrew to leave the area and Opal and Cindy embraced. However, later, Opal dragged Cindy out of the hospital by her arm, saying she must have said something to the doctor to tip him off, though Cindy swore she didn't. ''("[[Give a Little Bit]]")''

Erin later came back to the hospital. She said that she had gotten sicker and so Opal dropped her off on the side of the interstate, proclaiming her useless. At the hospital, she was examined again and told the doctors her real name and that she was from Scottsdale, Arizona. She'd been "discovered" on Snapchat. The photographer wanted to meet her, but her parents and sister all said it was sketchy. She decided to sneak out and go anyway and ended up spending two years being trafficked. Opal threatened to kill her if she ran away and said she'd take her sister if she told anyone. She had surgery to repair her hernia and was given IV antibiotics post-op. When she was found, her sister, Abby, was going to school in Portland and came to Seattle, where they were happily reunited. ''("[[All Tomorrow's Parties]]")''

'''Father Christopher''' is the priest who was marrying Teddy and Owen when some cyclists crashed into them.


Father Christopher came to the park to marry Teddy and Owen one day. He had nearly finished the ceremony when a tandem bike being ridden by [[Emma Correa|Emma]] and [[Nadia Correa]] crashed into the wedding, crushing him. Owen and Teddy rode with him in the ambulance to the hospital, where they did a pericardiocentesis in the ER before taking him into surgery. In surgery, they resected part of his lung and tried to repair the other damage, but they were unsuccessful and he died.



His niece came to the hospital when she learned he was injured. When she was told he had died, she said that he had died doing what he loved: marrying people.


He is a priest at [[Evelyn Hunt|Evelyn Hunt's]] church.

'''Felix Pelgado''' is a patient who was diagnosed with a brain tumor after having shoulder surgery.


Felix had surgery to repair a tear in his shoulder. Four months later, during a follow-up visit with his surgeon, Link, he complained that he still wasn't able to pitch at the same level as before his injury. While he was talking to Link, Amelia walked in and saw him struggle to open a water bottle with his right hand before switching to his left, making her think he had a neurological problem causing one-sided weakness. She asked him to come to the hospital for an MRI, which showed a meningioma at C-C. She took him into surgery, where she removed the whole tumor. After surgery, he was stable and awake and had improved strength in his arms.


*He plays baseball at a junior college and hopes to be recruited to a Division  school.

'''Fernanda Lima''' is a child who came to the hospital to have heart surgery.


Fernanda had congenital heart disease that caused aortic stenosis. She'd had two prior open-heart surgeries and made a trip with her family from Boston to Seattle for a third. Her condition made it unsafe for her to fly on a commercial airplane, so her parents used a crowdfunding website to raise money, which they used to get an RV and drive across the country. On the way, they stopped at several tourist attractions. By the time they reached Seattle, Fernanda was starting to feel dizzy, so they rushed her directly to the PICU. She was dehydrated, so they gave her fluids and ordered more tests, which showed that her aortic stenosis had gotten worse and they were forced to covert to a Ross-Konno Procedure. It carried additional risk, but her parents agreed to it because Maggie said it was the best option. The surgery went well and her family was told she'd be okay.



When she and her family had to travel from Boston to Seattle for her to have heart surgery, they took the time to spend together as a family, stopping at tourist sites along the way.


*She was thirteen at the time of her surgery.
*She loves salted caramel ice cream and action movies.
*She and her family are Brazilian.

'''Finley Calhoun''' is the wife of [[Elliott Calhoun]].


Finley's husband, Elliott, was in the hospital for his fourth aortic valve replacement due to congenital aortic stenosis. While he was fasting in preparation for his surgery, Finley's water broke, a month before her due date. Their son, Jasper, was born that day, one month early. He was taken to the NICU, where he was said to be doing well. Elliott was taken into surgery. His valve replacement went well, but his heart didn't restart when they were finished like it should have. Teddy believed it was due to hibernating myocardium and said they just needed to give Elliott more time. They told Finley about this and she was upset that they couldn't tell her definitively that it would work. ''("[[Let's All Go to the Bar]]")''

Not long afterward, Finley was waiting by Elliott's bedside when his heart started to beat again. Andrew weaned him off the ECMO and pacing wires and Finley thanked Andrew for his work. ''("[[Help Me Through the Night]]")''



She is married to [[Elliott Calhoun]].


She and her husband have one son, Jasper, who was born a month early.

'''Frances Pinfield''' is a woman who came from London to donate blood to [[Gus Carter]].


Frances came to the United States after learning that there was [[Gus Carter|a boy]] who needed her exact blood type, Rhnull, a very rare type. As she is severely agoraphobic, she traveled with her therapist, [[Dr. Safavi]], who had been working with her for two years to get her out of the house. However, when a paperwork snafu held Dr. Safavi up at the airport, Frances struggled to get off the plane. Owen brought a blood donation kit to the airplane, but Frances refused to have her blood drawn on the plane because she feared something would go wrong. She still struggled with getting off the plane, so Owen set up a video call with Gus's mom, who talked to her and explained why Gus needed her blood so badly. Frances was then able to allow Owen to carry her to the car while she was covered with a blanket. They made it to the car, but a fog settled in while they were on their way to the hospital, trapping them in a mess of traffic and accidents. ''("[[Drawn to the Blood]]")''

After the traffic settled a little, Owen got out of the car and spotted an ambulance. He carried Frances to the ambulance and they rode along with the patient to the hospital. Frances was immediately taken to the emotion room filled with plants, where she was given juice and cookies while her blood was drawn. The blood was then transfused into Gus, who quickly improved. Frances looked on along with Gus's mother while he played a video game in his bed. His mother hugged Frances and thanked her for what she'd done. ''("[[Jump Into the Fog]]")''


*She has severe agoraphobia and anxiety.
*She sings "Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go" by Wham! to calm herself down.<ref>[[Drawn to the Blood]], x</ref>

'''Francesca Lyons''' is a patient who came into the ER with back pain and was diagnosed with endometriosis.


Francesca came into the ER with pain in her lower back. She'd been in twice before with the same complaint. Amelia had given her epidurals both time. She said the fire week after the injections, she felt great, but then the pain came back. When she mentioned that she was on her period and having horrible cramps in addition to the back pain, Amelia called for a GYN consult. Carina and Jo came and examined her. Francesca explained that she'd been having severe pain with her periods since middle school, so Carina asked if she'd ever been evaluated for endometriosis. She explained the condition and then agreed to do a diagnostic surgery that same day. They took her into surgery, where the diagnosis was confirmed. They removed some of the tissue and then started her on low-dose, continuous birth control to help manage her symptoms.



She has a boyfriend who has a boat, which she normally hates. She decided to go with it because he's so hot.


*She was  at the time of her diagnosis.

'''Frank Nelstadt''' is a patient who coughed up a very large blood clot.


Frank came into the ER with his daughter, Ella, when he had a very severe cough and sore throat. He'd had the cough for a few days and wasn't concerned, but Ella was worried and made him go to the hospital. While he was being examined, he had trouble breathing, which was resolved when he coughed up a blood clot which was shaped like a bronchial tree. When he started to struggle to breathe again, he was taken to have TPA injected to break up the clot. He was then diagnosed with Factor V leiden. As the condition is genetic, Frank's husband, [[Danny Nelstadt|Danny]], immediately said Ella needed to be tested. They never wanted to know which of them was her biological father, but knew they needed to know if she had the same kind of condition, so she could properly maintain her health. The test came back positive, though Ella said it didn't matter because they're both her dads.



He is married to [[Danny Nelstadt]].


He and his husband have one daughter. When they had her, they chose not to know which of them was the biological father, unless she eventually wanted to know.


*He was  at the time of his hospitalization.

{{DEFAULTSORT:Nelstadt, Frank}}

'''Frankie Baner''' is a child who had an AVM.


Frankie had had a stroke due to a disorder that made his blood clot more readily than normal. He was in the hospital to have an AVM embolization when the computers were hacked and blocked access to Frankie's medical records. This left them unsure of if he got the vitamin K to reverse his anti-coagulants. When Frankie developed a headache, they ran a CT, but it didn't show anything, though it was likely it was too early to see anything. As he worsened, Jo raced around the hospital, trying to track down the nurses who had worked on Frankie to see whether he'd gotten the vitamin K or not. Meanwhile, Alex and Amelia continued monitoring him and decided based on his medical history to give him the heparin, just as Jo learned that he hadn't gotten his vitamin K, so heparin would kill him. ''("[[Out of Nowhere]]")''

After he was given the heparin, Frankie got worse instead of better, tipping them off that it had been the wrong choice. They took him for an angio, which showed a bleed. They took him into surgery to place a shunt and they were able to stop the bleeding. He was stable and awake afterward. ''("[[---]]")''



His mother had a crush on Alex and told her sister that he was stupid hot. When Frankie thought he was dying, he asked Alex to marry his mom if he died. ''("[[Out of Nowhere]]")''

When he woke up after his surgery, he asked if Alex would still marry his mom even though he didn't die. ''("[[---]]")''


*He was seven years old at the time of his hospitalization.<ref>[[Out of Nowhere]], x</ref>

'''Gabe''' is the nephew of [[Claire Conway]].


Gabe was at a convenience store with his Aunt Claire and his brother, [[Eli]], when his aunt collapsed. They accompanied her to the ER, where she was diagnosed with toxic megacolon and had surgery to remove a portion of her colon. After the surgery, Claire talked to Gabe and Eli about how scary it had been when she collapsed and sent them to the cafeteria to get pizza to eat.



He started living with his aunt and brother after their mother died.


*He had a project due the day after his aunt's hospitalization and only told her that day, while she was sick.

'''Gabriella Rivera''' is a child who was diagnosed with cancer after coming to the hospital with abdominal pain.


Gabby came to the clinic with her father because she was experiencing severe abdominal pain. Because she'd been detained at the border with her mother, her father didn't know how long she'd been in pain and the detention center only gave her an antacid to treat her. She had an intestinal blockage, which they were unable to resolve with an enema. She was then taken into surgery, where they took a biopsy while they resolved her blockage. The biopsy diagnosed her with Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Because her father was uninsured, but made too much money to qualify for Medicaid for Gabby, Meredith used [[Ellis Shepherd|her daughter's]] name and insurance on the paperwork to get it covered. When Richard found out about it, he was upset that she'd committed insurance fraud, but knew of a program that would kick in after  days if they could keep Gabby in the hospital the whole time, so they had to get creative about ways to justify her continuous time in the hospital. In the meantime, they encouraged Luis to go back to work to occupy his time and offered him a cot so he could sleep in Gabby's room with her. ''("[[What I Did for Love]]")''

Gabby continued to stay in the hospital. When she had to have an MRI, she was scared, so Andrew did an MRI on her stuffed kitty, Perla, first to show her that it wasn't going to hurt her. ''("[[Drawn to the Blood]]")''

Gabby's staging results came back and showed that it was only stage . After Bailey told them this, Catherine said the Foundation would cover her treatment and associated costs. She also shared her own experience with cancer and said they'd do whatever they could to make sure Gabby was okay. ''("[[Jump Into the Fog]]")''


On the day of Meredith's hearing to determine if she would lose her medical license, Gabby came to the hearing along with her father, who testified. When Gabby saw Meredith, she ran to her and gave her a hug. ''("[[My Shot]]")''



Her father came to the United States to get settled before sending for Gabby and her mom. When he sent for them, they were detained at the border until Gabby was finally released to him.


*She was four years old at the time of her diagnosis.
*She and her family are from San Pedro Sula, Honduras.

'''Garrett Boland''' is the fianc\ue of [[Natasha Deon]].


Garrett came to the hospital with his fianc\uee, [[Natasha Deon]], after she fell from a balcony the night before their wedding. He waited while she had surgery for her broken pelvis and internal injuries. After her surgery, he sat by her bedside as she lay in a medically-induced coma. ''("[[Help, I'm Alive]]")''

Garrett waited by Natasha's bedside for weeks while she slept. After a month, they took her off the sedatives, and she woke up on Christmas Eve. On New Years Eve, she was off the ventilator and speaking. However, after that, she started to decline again. She was put on dialysis and back on the ventilator. After  days in the hospital, Natasha and Garrett decided to have the doctors turn the ventilator off. They then gave them the wedding they wanted, with phones displaying star pictures, in her hospital room, right before she died. ''("[[Girlfriend in a Coma]]")''



He is engaged to [[Natasha Deon]]. After her ventilator was turned off, they got married right before she died. ''("[[Girlfriend in a Coma]]")''

'''Gavin Hawj''' is a research assistant at [[The Grey Center]].


Gavin was working with the team at The Grey Center to develop a cure for Parkinson's. When David Hamilton put extra pressure on them to work faster, he helped test various options. They were able to make some improvement, but not enough to meet the FDA's requirement for compassionate release. They continued to try different options to keep the cells cool enough until Amelia had the idea to cool the needle they were using to inject them. They ran several trials with the needles at different temperatures. One of the trials was successful at giving them a % viability.


He is a research assistant and tech genius at [[The Grey Center]]. He built the motorized injector they were using to inject the cells.

During the wind storm, Georgia's glass door shattered, sending glass at her. She had many tiny shards in her skin, plus one large one in her abdomen. Link checked the nerve function in her hand, where she had a large cut, which came out fine. Her minor wounds were stitched and then she was taken to surgery to remove the large piece of glass and repair her abdomen.

'''Gerlie Bernardo''' is a patient who spent over eight months in the hospital due to COVID-.


Gerlie, was in the hospital with COVID, which she believed she'd gotten at the assisted living facility where she worked from a man named Earl. Bailey examined her and ordered high-flow oxygen, chest films, steroids, and Remdesivir. She spent two weeks on a ventilator.

A month later, in September, Gerlie was discharged from the hospital to go home and finish recovering. She was warned not to try returning to work too soon. However, as she went to leave the hospital, she collapsed and had to be taken back inside. In October, Gerlie was still fighting her post-COVID complications in the hospital. She'd had a VATS procedure and had a pneumothorax and multifocal pneumonia. Meredith did a bronchoscope on her.

On December , she had to be put on ECMO. In January , Meredith asked to put her on the transplant list for lungs, a request Bailey denied due to her risk of sudden death. Meredith put pressure on Bailey and she ultimately agreed to the transplant. In April , they found a donor and Gerlie received her lung transplant, which was successful. Gerlie woke up after her surgery surprised to see Meredith sitting by her bedside. Meredith promised Gerlie that she wasn't going anywhere.



She has a good relationship with her patient, Earl. When she was hospitalized, she was eager to get back to him.


She is a nurse at Lakeforest Assisted Living. At her job, she'd been caring for a man named Earl for seven years.


She was  at the time of her initial admission to the hospital.

'''Gus Carter''' is a patient who was diagnosed with a thymoma.


Gus came into the ER after sixteen days having a cough and recurrent sinus infection. Due to his autism, he wouldn't let the doctors examine him, so Alex used his love of buildings and LEGO to talk to him. Gus was able to use LEGO to show Alex that he had significant pain in his chest. They ran a chest CT, which showed a thymoma, which Maggie noted is always malignant in children, but curable with surgery. However, before they could operate, he needed a blood transfusion as he was anemic. They got him blood, but he rejected it because it wasn't the right type. They re-typed his blood and showed AB, but with no Rh antigen, an extremely rare occurrence. Before he could have surgery, they needed to find blood donors who were an exact match to his blood so he wouldn't reject it. They identified only four potential donors in the world, but Alex promised his parents they'd keep looking until they found the blood he needed. ''("[[The Whole Package]]")''

During his stay at the hospital, Gus continued to build with LEGO kits, including one of the Arc de Triomphe. ''("[[Head Over High Heels]]")''

The wait was thought to be over when a call came in from Canada from a doctor treating a patient who was also Rh<sub>null</sub>. However, this was a misunderstanding and the doctor was hoping to find a donor for her patient, not offering her patient as a donor. When Gus's mother found out about the error, she was upset. ''("[[What I Did for Love]]")''

Over time, Gus got so weak, he couldn't build his LEGO kits anymore. A blood donor was found in London, but she had severe agoraphobia, making the trip to the United States extremely difficult for her, even with her therapist. When her therapist was detained at the airport, she struggled even more and refused to leave the plane. However, after a call with Lori and meeting Gus, who was unconscious after having a heart attack, she agreed to be carried off the plane. She got into the car, but then a fog settled in, so they were stuck in traffic. Gus's organs continued to fail because of oxygen debt, so Alex took him to the hyperbaric chamber, in the hopes it would give him enough time to wait for the blood transfusion. ''("[[Drawn to the Blood]]")''

In the hyperbaric chamber, Gus was able to get more oxygen to his organs. However, he still coded, so they started decompressing the chamber as Frances was still on her way to the hospital with Owen. Alex did chest compressions and refused to stop until the blood had been transfused, at which point, he went back into sinus rhythm and regained consciousness. He immediately started to get stronger and his mother and Frances both watched as he was able to play a video game in his bed. ''("[[Jump Into the Fog]]")''


*Gus is autistic.
*Every Saturday, he and his parents get bagels and eat them outside the Smith building, but hadn't been since he got sick. ''("[[The Whole Package]]")''
*He's very interested in buildings and architecture, especially the Smith building.

'''Guthrie Hamilton''' is the son of [[Dana Hamilton]].


Guthrie was making croissants in a pastry class when he collapsed. He was diagnosed with a brain tumor which had spread to his spine, causing motor weakness in his limbs and sensory deficits. His mom, desperate to save him, took him to Grey Sloan Memorial to see her ex-husband, Tom, a neurosurgeon. Before they met, she warned Guthrie that since he looked like his deceased brother, it might freak Tom out to meet him. Due to the resemblance and the relationship to Guthrie's mother, Tom said he couldn't do the surgery. However, when Amelia started having contractions during the surgery and believed she was in labor, Tom was forced to step in and take over. Despite a hiccup, he was able to finish the surgery and Dana and Ed were told he'd be okay with some radiation.



His half-brother, David, died before he was born. He bears a striking resemblance to David.


*He was ten years old at the time of his surgery.
*He asks everyone what single food they'd bring to a deserted island.

'''Guy Houston''' is a young man who was hit by a rubber bullet at the seattle protests.


Guy was protesting in Seattle when he was hit by a rubber bullet fired into the crowd. He was defibrillated in the field and then taken to the hospital, where Maggie saw no fluid around his heart on ultrasound. However, he did have commotio cordis, an interruption of his heart rhythm. She wanted him admitted for observation, but when he coded again in the ER, she said she believed the impact had bruised his heart. He coded a third time and Maggie realized he wouldn't stop until they did the ablation, so he was taken for radio frequency ablation, which was successful. After his procedure, Maggie talked to his mother and told her he'd be okay.



His father has had two heart attacks.


*He was  at the time of his hospitalization.

'''Gwendolyn Yates''' is a patient who was in the hospital awaiting a heart transplant.


Gwendolyn had a history of cardiac amyloidosis for which she had been taking medication for years. She came to the hospital with worsening shortness of breath and edema. Maggie told her her protein deposits had caused congestive heart failure. She was also developing clots, requiring an IVC filter. She was told she'd have to remain in the ICU until a heart transplant came through. Gwen had no family after her husband had died the prior October. She had adopted a dog named Jupiter, but Jupiter got out of the house during a storm and her condition left her so exhausted she couldn't look for him.

A few weeks later, Gwen had her heart transplant. Once her new heart was in, the edema resolved and her condition improved, but she told the doctors she had woken up with a headache that was worsening, so they paged neuro. A week of exams and scans were all normal, though her headaches persisted. Gwen later admitted to faking the headaches because she didn't want to go home. Gwen was ultimately discharged. As she left the hospital, Richard surprised her with her dog. He'd used the interns to call shelters and locate him. Gwen happily took Jupiter and went home.



Her husband had died less than a year prior to her hospitalization.


*She was  at the time of her heart transplant.

'''Hadley''' is the sister of [[Suzanne Britland]].


Hadley's sister, Suzanne, was post-op day three on an appendectomy, but still in the hospital because she had a high white count and fever, but no sepsis. She admitted to a sore throat during rounds, but hoped to get some antibiotics and get discharged that day anyway. Her daughters were missing school because they refused to leave the hospital without her after losing their father less than a year prior after a doctor said he'd be okay and sent him home. They did a CT and during the CT, she crashed and they were forced to do a pericardiocentesis in the CT booth to relieve the cardiac tamponade. They sent the fluid to the lab for testing, but had to admit they didn't know what was going on with her. ''("[[A Hard Pill to Swallow]]")''

Desperate, Andrew called in [[Lauren Riley]], an expert diagnostician from UCSF. After having Maggie do a pericardial window to relieve the pressure of the fluid around her heart, Lauren said they need to withdraw all treatment, so that they could see the symptoms without the medications. Suzanne was reluctant, but ultimately agreed to let them withdraw all treatments. ''("[[Save the Last Dance for Me]]")''

Suzanne's previously treated symptoms started to appear again, causing discomfort. They continued to run tests, which still didn't show anything conclusive. Finally, after Andrew noticed that Suzanne's platelet count had dropped almost to zero, they did a bone marrow biopsy. That showed hemophagocytosis, a result of macrophage activation syndrome, a known complication of Still's disease, which she had prior to the appendectomy without knowing it. They have her high-dose steroids, which caused her to feel better almost immediately and said she'd be referred to a rheumatologist to manage her condition. ''("[[A Diagnosis]]")''



She is close with her sister and was very concerned when she was hospitalized for several days.


*She never wanted children.

'''Hank Giles''' is the son of [[Doug Giles|Doug]] and [[Cheryl Giles]].


Hank's father had just bought a new motorcycle and he and her mom went for a ride around the block and Doug swerved to avoid hitting a dog. Hank's sister, Wynnie, drove them to the hospital in their van with only a learner's permit. In the ER, they learned that while Cheryl had only cuts and bruises on her hand, Doug had a serious head injury because Cheryl had been wearing the only helmet. She said she didn't even like the motorcycle, but she liked seeing Doug in the garage with it and it stirred up feelings. While her hands were bandaged, Doug was taken into surgery to treat a brain bleed. After his surgery, he was expected to recover fully and said he'd be getting rid of the motorcycle.



He came to the hospital with his sister and parents when his parents crashed their dad's motorcycle.


*He wanted to keep the dog they almost hit, but his mom told him he couldn't.

'''Hazel Talbert''' is the wife of [[Margot Talbert]].


Hazel's wife, Margot, came into the ER with throbbing abdominal pain that radiated to her back. She told the doctors it had started that morning. They examined her and find that her abdomen was pulsating, so they ordered a CT, which showed an abdominal aortic aneurysm. While she was in the CT, they asked if she could call anyone for her and she said no. She admitted that she'd been having the pain for a few months and said Hazel would be angry to know she hadn't gotten it looked out because she told Hazel she had. As they prepared for her surgery, Winston informed her they were obligated to notify next of kin and would be calling her wife. Margot was upset by that and Maggie told her that wasn't necessarily true. Winston asked her what would happen if she died. Margot then coded, because her aneurysm had ruptured. They rushed to start her surgery and were able to repair the damage. After her surgery, Hazel came to see her and thanked the doctors for saving her life.



She is married to [[Margot Talbert]].

'''Heather Young''' is the wife of [[Noah Young]].


Heather came to the hospital with her son, Danny, when she heard that her husband, Noah, had collapsed at work while bagging groceries. She expressed regret at letting him get a job as she knew that, due to pulmonary fibrosis, he didn't have the stamina to get through a whole shift. However, he had insisted because the pills were piling up. At the hospital, she waited while Noah had tests and got some treatments to help him breathe. When Bailey came to find her, she was struggling not to cry. She spoke briefly with Bailey about her struggle with Noah dying. Bailey took Heather to a patient room and gave her permission to break down, as she'd been holding it together for her husband and her son.

Later, with his chest tube in, Noah asked Owen how much longer it would be before it was over. Owen said it would be soon. He helped Owen get ready and the family left the hospital together. ''("[[Everyday Is a Holiday (With You)]]")''

Noah later died after taking medication Owen provided to him to hasten his death. ''("[[It Came Upon a Midnight Clear]]")''

With Noah gone, Heather worked with Owen to get the same medication to other soldiers with the same condition who didn't live in states where physician-assisted suicide was an option for them. After Owen was in an accident, she came to the hospital to get his car key so she could get the medicine out of his car to distribute it. While she was doing this, Teddy followed her and told her she would call the police if Heather didn't tell her what the medication was. ''("[[Living In a House Divided]]")''

Later, Heather told [[John (Out for Blood)|John]] what Owen had done and sent John to Seattle to get the same treatment for his wife. When Owen tried calling her to ask her about it, she didn't answer his call. ''("[[Out for Blood]]")''



She was married to [[Noah Young]] until his death.


She and her husband have one son, Danny.

'''Herschel Kitano''' is the husband of [[Vera Kitano]].


Herschel was reaching for a large book in his and his wife's home office when he dropped it, hitting his wife's foot. She went to the ER, where they got an x-ray which showed fractures in two of her metatarsals. She had surgery to repair the fractures, but when she woke up afterward, she believed everyone else was singing when they weren't and believed she was talking when she was actually singing all her words. They got a neuro consult and she had an MRI, which showed no signs of a stroke or bleed. They decided to keep her overnight to monitor her and see if it was a side-effect of the anesthesia. Later that day, she developed a tension pneumothorax. They were able to relieve the pressure and she stabilized, but Herschel realized he just wanted her to be safe and sung to her that he loved her.



He is married to [[Vera Kitano]].


He is a professor at the University of Washington, like his wife.


*He once had a car in which the seat belt alert was broken and beeped all the time.

'''Hunter Martinez''' is a baseball player with osteosarcoma in his right leg.


Hunter had been diagnosed with osteosarcoma in his right femur. After three months of chemotherapy, the doctors were ready for the next step of his treatment: removing the cancerous portion of his leg and then turning his lower leg around and attaching it to the upper part, making his ankle take the place of his knee. The hope was that with prosthetics and rehab, he'd be able to play baseball again. His surgery went well and, while his leg looked odd to him at first, the doctors were hopeful that he'd be able to play as well as he'd played before.



His mother, [[Jenny Martinez]], was upset to learn that Hunter had known about his cancer for three months and hadn't told her. His reasoning for not telling her was that he knew she'd worry.


He knew [[Atticus Lincoln|Link]] from his time working for the Mariners.


He's a minor league baseball player. He hopes that with his new leg and prosthetics, he'll be called up to the majors.


*He was  at the time of his surgery.
*He wears #.

'''Irene Sholman''' is a woman with stage four cancer who came into the ER.


Irene came into the ER with pain in her abdomen. Levi examined her and said he believed she had a bowel obstruction. Irene's husband, Norman, then told Levi that Irene also had colorectal cancer. He ordered a CT scan, which showed multiple mets in her liver and lungs as well as the obstruction. Meredith told Irene she wasn't confident she'd recover from surgery, so they offered her palliative care.

Wanting to do something special for Irene, her husband Norman enlisted the help of Levi and some other residents to make the cafeteria into a dance floor. They disconnected her oxygen and draped a gown around her and she and Norman danced around the floor.



She is married to [[Norman Sholman]].


She and her husband have at least two children and at least one grandson together.

'''Ivan''' is a man who came into the ER with a python wrapped around his body.


Ivan was feeding his Burmese python, Gigi, when she bit his arm instead of her food. Then she wrapped her body around his and began constricting. Ivan's boyfriend, [[Clark (Put the Squeeze On Me)|Clark]], put him in the back of the car and drove him to the hospital. Once they arrived, several doctors came out to assess Ivan. Ivan kept insisting that it looked worse than it was and that Gigi hadn't meant any harm. When Animal Control was delayed, Winston had the idea to spray Gigi with alcohol, which would irritate her eyes and get her to release her jaw so they could free him. Bailey did that and then Winston, Jordan, and Link unwrapped Gigi from Ivan's body. Then they got him onto a gurney and took him inside.

In the ER, he had reduced oxygen and a chest x-ray showed opacity in his chest. Richard believed it was a hemothorax and wanted to insert a chest tube, but Bailey said no and insisted on a CT, which showed that Ivan actually had a diaphragmatic rupture and the opacity was his abdominal organs, which had been compressed into his chest cavity. They took him into surgery, where they moved his organs back into his abdomen. When he started coding and went into DIC, they were forced to stop the surgery, pack him, and move him to the ICU.

On the way to the ICU, he coded again, and Bailey did chest compressions until they got him into his room, where they defibrillated. They were able to stabilize him enough that his boyfriend was able to sit with him. The hope was that they could continue his surgery the next day.



He is dating [[Clark (Put the Squeeze On Me)|Clark]].


He is a second grade teacher. He initially purchased Gigi for his class, but had to take her home when she got too big.

'''J.J. Williams''' is a kid whose cancer was discovered after he broke his arm.


J.J. fell while trying to climb the fence with his friend and broke his arm. He was examined in the ER and an x-ray was ordered to confirm. It confirmed the break, but also revealed a mass, which a biopsy showed was osteosarcoma. J.J.'s mother, Michelle, was worried about him dying and J.J. was worried about being bald, but Link reassured them both, saying he had the same kind of cancer when he was a kid and survived and letting J.J. cut his hair.



He has a grandfather who is bald.

'''Jai Prishna''' is a man who fell off a cliff while taking a picture.


Jai and his wife, Mari, were hiking. When they finished their hike, they stopped to take a picture. Jai stepped slightly back to take the photo and slipped off the cliff behind them. Mari grabbed onto the rope he was hanging from and, despite having an injury to her own shoulder, held on for several hours until Jackson, who was out walking after leaving Maggie in the woods, found them and helped Mari hold on. They stayed like that until Vic Hughes arrived and held wench him up. Mari and Jai were both taken to the hospital, where each had emergency surgery, her on her arms and him on his legs.

A week later, They were both recovering nicely from their initial surgeries. The doctors had managed to save both Jai's legs and Mari's fracture was healing, but she needed a second surgery to do nerve repair. Mari's surgery went well.

A week after that, Jai lost consciousness suddenly in his hospital room and Mari called for help. They diagnosed watershed infarctions, but had no idea what was causing them as he was young and healthy.

Another week later, Jai was on life support, something Mari knew he would hate. She planned to take him off life support, but just as they were doing so, Link and Amelia came in with something Amelia remembered about a past patient, who had a fat embolus come off a break and go to his brain. It looked the same as Jai and caused a tell-tale rash. She searched Jai's body for the rash and found it under his arm. They told Mari they might be able to wake Jai up.

For a week, Jai had experimental treatments, but still hadn't woken up. Mari wanted to stop treatments, worried it would make Jai just better enough that he wouldn't die. Andrew convinced her that it wasn't time yet to give up on Jai.

After another week of treatment, Mari had found a long-term care facility for Jai. However, she was surprised when the doctors took her to his room and he was awake. His exams all looked good, but he was still very weak. Mari kissed him and thanked all the doctors.



He is married to [[Mari Prishna]]. They like to go hiking together. When he fell off a cliff while taking a selfie, she held him up for hours until help arrived.


*He was  at the time of his hospitalization.

'''Jamal Clark''' is the son of [[Simon Clark|Simon]] and [[Kristen Clark]].


Jamal's parents tried for three years to conceive after his father was diagnosed with cancer. When his cancer returned while Kristen was pregnant, Simon was desperate to live long enough to meet his son before he died. ''("[[I'll Cover You]]")'' Simon started chemotherapy treatments with the hope that it would give him enough time to get Kristen to a safe point to have a c-section. During this time, she had some contractions, but they were determined to be Braxton-Hicks. ''("[[Stronger Than Hate]]

When Kristen got to  weeks, they started to worry that Simon wouldn't make it and put him on ECMO to buy him just a little more time. ''("[[Out for Blood]]")'' Soon afterward, Kristen experienced a placental abruption, forcing an immediate c-section delivery. As soon as he was cleared, Jamal was taken down to see his father, who kissed him and told him hello forever before dying. ''("[[You Are the Blood]]")''



His father always wanted to be a dad.


*Though his dad has an uncle named Jamal, he was named after his mother.

'''Jamarah Blake''' is an employee of the Medical Accreditation Council who came to Grey Sloan to investigate their residency program.


Jamarah came to Grey Sloan with [[MaryAnn Suchan]] to investigate their residency program after receiving anonymous complaints. For this investigation, they interviewed the attendings about the program. They wanted to interview residents, but they were all on grand rounds with [[Nick Marsh]], except [[Levi Schmitt]], who had left the program. They noted that the program had lost seven surgeons in the last year as Bailey showed them around the hospital.

Once the tour was over, they began interviewing attendings, all of whom defended the program and its efficacy. They also interviewed [[Jo Wilson]], who spoke about her decision to change from surgery to obstetrics, but still defended the surgical residency program. After speaking to her, they asked to speak to Richard next. Bailey suggested they go take a break and she'd bring him to them. At the end of the day, they said that they had a top-quality program, but they simply didn't have enough surgeons to keep the program running. They put the program on probation and left Bailey a list of concrete steps she needed to take before their return in a few weeks, telling her if she didn't make the changes, the program would be shut down. ''("[[Put It to the Test]]")''

Jamarah returned at a later date and was pleased that they'd corrected the issues she flagged. She came concerned, however, when she saw that many of the hospital's surgical residents were donating blood during their shifts. Bailey assured her it was strictly voluntary and only due to the nationwide blood shortage. Jamarah then observed from the gallery while Meredith and Nick attempted to remove [[Cora|a large pancreatic head tumor]]. During the surgery, she was shocked to learn that Meredith was leaving the hospital. ''("[[Out for Blood]]")''

Jamarah then met Jackson, who said the Foundation was committed to Grey Sloan's success and was putting additional funding into the hospital to make it better. Jamarah confronted him over Meredith leaving, saying it made her wonder what else Jackson was hiding. She then went to Bailey and asked if she knew that the hospital had been closed to trauma. She said she didn't, but she wasn't surprised. At the end of the day, Jamarah told Bailey that she'd seen often how sometimes programs suffered because people worked together for so long that they no longer respected the authority of the people in charge. She told Bailey she was shutting down the program and re-assigning the residents. She told Bailey to take the time to rebuild and start over. ''("[[You Are the Blood]]")''


She works for the Medical Accreditation Council.

'''James Chee''' is a surgical resident at Grey Sloan Memorial who started near the beginning of the pandemic.



Due to the growing Covid- pandemic, James and his fellow medical school graduates were sent to their residency programs earlier than the standard start date. They arrived on the first day and were welcomed reluctantly by [[Tom Koracick]]. James was assigned to do progress notes on the patients. He then left them tape and a marker to make name tags for themselves before leaving them.

After two hours of working on progress notes for patients, James hadn't even finished one, angering [[Karen (Season )|Karen]], who was waiting for them. Tom stepped in and noted that his problem was that he kept putting, "Home and awaiting follow-up" for patients who had died. All the patients had died, which created an error. Tom fixed the problem and told James to carry on. ''("[[My Happy Ending]]")''

One day, James brought a patient into the hyperbaric chamber for wound therapy. Due to a busy schedule, his patient was scheduled for the same slot as Meredith. While they waited in the chamber, James asked Levi if Meredith was mean, as that's what he'd heard, but she got sick before he could work with her. Levi emphatically stated that she could be tough, but she was not mean. When James' patient started to wake up and eviscerated himself, Levi helped keep James calm and then pack his intestines back in. Then he had James call for the chamber to be depressurized so the patient could be moved back to the OR. ''("[[Sign O' the Times]]")''

James observed a laminectomy for a meningioma that Amelia was performing. Link was also in the gallery. When Amelia did her superhero pose before starting the surgery, James asked what she was doing and Link said she was preparing to crush it. ''("[[Good as Hell]]")''

During his days off, James volunteered at the urban Indian Health Clinic. Through his work there, he met [[William Lawrence]]. He treated William for COVID, but William later returned to the clinic having what appeared to be a stroke. James accompanied him to the hospital where the stroke was confirmed and he had a thrombectomy. After his thrombectomy, James went to his room and used some traditional medicine for William. ''("[[Tradition]]")''


When Meredith took over the residency program at the hospital, she cancelled grand rounds in favor of having the residents shadow her on Gerlie's case, as she suffered through multiple post-COVID complications.

In January, James was able to get his first dose of the COVID- vaccine along with the rest of the hospital staff. Meredith also had the residents still working on Gerlie's case, specifically trying to get Bailey to put Gerlie on the list for a double lung transplant. Finally, Bailey agreed and in April , Gerlie got her lungs. ''("[[Someone Saved My Life Tonight]]")''


In order to inspire the residents and help them catch up on their surgical education, Richard had them all come in early one morning to start a surgical contest starting in the skills lab. He explained that they'd be judge in four areas: laparascopic, suturing, vascular skills, and endoscopic techniques. At the end of the day, the resident with the highest score would scrub in on a surgery at their skill level. They started with laparascopic skills. After that, they practiced sutures. He gave them  seconds to tie three square knots without moving the soda can where the ties were attached. When the time was up, Link declared Levi the winner. They also used a computer came to practice endoscopic skills, with Mabel beating Taryn when they went head-to-head. After that finished, with all points tallied, Richard declared Levi the overall winner and said he'd get to scrub in on [[Robin Jeter]], who had a foreign body obstructing her intestines.

The extraction went well, with Taryn assisting, but when he went to close, he struggled. Bailey turned on the speaker in the gallery, where the other residents were watching, and they all offered up tips and with their help, Levi was able to finish the surgery and close. ''("[[Some Kind of Tomorrow]]")''


The residents were told they'd have a surprise guest for grand rounds one day. Right before it started, they learned that guest was [[Addison Forbes Montgomery]]. When they met, she quizzed Levi on a medical fact related to her case and when he got it right, told him he'd be presenting the case. She then took them to meet [[Tovah Freedman]], who had had a hysterectomy due to placental abruption and then had lost her husband. She was there in the hopes that a uterine transplant could help her conceive and carry a healthy pregnancy. The residents all observed the surgery and answered questions as Addison asked them until the HVAC system went offline and some of them were called away to help move patients and cancel surgeries. Despite this, Addison completed her surgery and afterward, the residents followed Meredith and Addison and continued their gossip. When they saw them exiting the elevator with Addison crying, they assumed Meredith had said something to make her cry. ''("[[Hotter Than Hell]]")''


Wanting to train up the residents quickly to avoid some of the fallout of the physician shortage, Richard deployed The Webber Method when he took back over as residency director. This involved having the residents take the lead on several cholecystectomy patients, operating on a staggered schedule so the attending could rotate through ORs to be available to help during the most complicated part of the surgery. Taryn faced a complication when her patient began bleeding profusely, forcing her to convert to an open procedure, but, with Bailey's help, she was able to finish the surgery successfully. In total,  patients were treated using this method. ''("[[With a Little Help From My Friends]]")''


He is a [[General Surgery|surgical]] [[Resident]] at [[Grey Sloan Memorial Hospital]]. Due to the COVID- pandemic during his [[Internship|intern year]], he and the rest of his residency class are behind a year of surgical education and is taking accelerated surgical courses under the direction of [[Richard Webber|Dr. Webber]]. 


*He is Din\ue (Navajo).
*He comes from a family of healers.<ref>[[Tradition]], x</ref>
